QAPair.Question: What is (are) Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Felty syndrome is a disorder that includes rheumatoid arthritis , a swollen spleen, decreased white blood cell count , and repeated infections. It is rare.

QAPair.Question: What causes Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: The cause of Felty syndrome is unknown. It is more common in people who have had rheumatoid arthritis (RA) for a long time. People with this syndrome are at risk for infection because they have a low white blood cell count.

QAPair.Question: What are the symptoms of Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Symptoms include: General feeling of discomfort ( malaise ), Fatigue, Weakness in leg or arm, Loss of appetite, Unintentional weight loss, Ulcers in the skin, Joint swelling , stiffness, pain, and deformity, Recurrent infections, Red eye with burning or discharge,

QAPair.Question: How to diagnose Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: A physical exam will show: Swollen spleen, Joints that show signs of RA, Possibly swollen liver and lymph nodes, A complete blood count ( CBC ) with differential will show a low number of white blood cells called neutrophils. Nearly all people with Felty syndrome have a positive test for rheumatoid factor. An abdominal ultrasound may confirm a swollen spleen.

QAPair.Question: What are the treatments for Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: In most cases, people who have this syndrome are not getting recommended treatment for RA. They may need other medicines to suppress their immune system and reduce the activity of their RA. Methotrexate may improve the low neutrophil count. The drug rituximab has been successful in people who do not respond to methotrexate. Granulocyte-colony stimulating factor (G-CSF) may raise the neutrophil count. Some people benefit from removal of the spleen ( splenectomy ).

QAPair.Question: What is the outlook for Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Without treatment, infections may continue to occur. RA is likely to get worse. Treating the RA, however, should improve Felty syndrome.

QAPair.Question: What are the complications of Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: You may have infections that keep coming back. Some people with Felty syndrome have increased numbers of large granular lymphocytes, also called LGL leukemia. This will be treated with methotrexate in many cases.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your health care provider if you develop symptoms of this disorder.

QAPair.Question: How to prevent Felty syndrome ?
QAPair.Answer: Prompt treatment of RA with currently recommended medicines markedly decreases the risk of developing Felty syndrome.
